TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , before the applicant ’s birth , the ORG - appointed guardian brought an action against ORG , the applicant ’s putative biological father , seeking a declaration of paternity and payment of a contribution towards his maintenance . PERSON admitted that he had had sexual relations with the applicant ’s mother but denied paternity .
CARDINAL . On DATE , after the applicant ’s birth , his mother declared on registering the birth that the father was PERSON , with whom she had had sexual relations during the period of conception .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG Instance dismissed the action for a declaration of paternity . In the absence of an appeal , the judgment became final .

NORP In DATE the applicant , who had been placed with a foster family , met his mother , who informed him that his father was PERSON According to the applicant , he had regular contact with his father and received presents from him and a DATE payment of MONEY ( ( CHF ) – PERSON euros ( EUR ) ) until he reached the age of majority . PERSON and his family denied those allegations . Only PERSON ’s legitimate son admitted that he had received a telephone call from the applicant after PERSON ’s death .

CARDINAL . Furthermore , ORG always refused to undergo tests to establish his paternity . In DATE , shortly after his death , a blood - type analysis carried out at the applicant ’s request did not rule out his being the latter ’s father .
CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant contacted ORG to have a private paternity test carried out , but his request was refused .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Canton of ORG rejected the applicant ’s application on the ground that it was impossible to obtain a declaration of paternity without also amending the register of births , deaths and marriages .

CARDINAL . ORG argued that the applicant was not entitled to such an amendment of the register as a result of the DATE revision of LAW abolishing the exceptio plurium constupratorum , a defence which the putative biological father could use in a paternity suit . However , in his application to ORG the applicant had sought revision of the DATE judgment , in which the exceptio plurium had been relied on to the benefit of ORG

CARDINAL . ORG noted that DATE ( when the revised Civil Code had come into force ) , an illegitimate child who was DATE on DATE had had the option of converting a maintenance claim into a civil action ( paternity suit ) where the exceptio plurium had been raised . However , this was no longer permitted under the revised Civil Code .

CARDINAL . ORG accordingly held that , even supposing that the applicant had been awarded maintenance in DATE , he was no longer entitled to have the register of births , deaths and marriages amended , firstly because the law had changed , and secondly because he had been born DATE before the end of the transition period between the old and new laws .
CARDINAL . His request for evidence to be taken by means of a DNA test was therefore refused .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG adopted a judgment , served on DATE , in which it rejected the applicant ’s application on the following grounds :

“ The right to know one ’s parentage can not be absolute in scope but must be weighed against the interests relating to protection of the personal freedom of others – in the instant case , the right of the deceased , deriving from human dignity , to protect his remains from interferences contrary to morality and custom , and the right of the close relatives to respect for the deceased and the inviolability of his corpse . ...

The right to know one ’s parents is generally linked to the right to be raised by them . The applicant , who is DATE , has been able to develop his personality and pursue a large portion of his existence without suffering any medically attested damage to his physical or mental health as a result of his uncertainty as to his parentage , despite the vicissitudes of his childhood and adolescence . On the other hand , while the reasons of family devotion opposing the exhumation of the mortal remains of the late [ ORG ] are understandable , the respondents have not advanced any religious or philosophical grounds in support of their position ; in particular , they have not argued that they would have renewed the lease on their relative ’s tomb had the applicant not done so .

However , in weighing up the conflicting interests , the refusal of the application for an expert examination may be upheld since , in the absence of any consequences of a civil - law nature , the applicant has not established that he has suffered sufficiently serious damage to his psychological well - being , as protected by the right to personal freedom , to justify the evidentiary measure requested . The measure appears excessive in view of the principle of proportionality , having regard to the applicant ’s particular circumstances , from which it can not be concluded that his personality or mental stability might be seriously threatened by the uncertainty that may still persist as regards his parentage , in spite of all the information in his possession suggesting that [ ORG ] very probably is his father . ORG was therefore entitled to restrict the applicant ’s personal freedom by taking into consideration that of the respondents , in view of the lack of public interest in having this parental tie established and the disproportionate nature of the steps required to establish it . ”
CARDINAL . Lastly , ORG observed that there were no consequences of a civil - law nature that could justify implementing the measure sought .
